Literature Review: Lysosomal ion channels have been a subject of increasing interest in recent years due to their crucial roles in various cellular processes. These channels and transporters are essential for maintaining the permeability of lysosomes to major ions, including K+, Na+, H+, Ca2+, and Clâˆ’. The discovery of unique lysosomal ion channels and transporters, such as TPCs, TMEM175, TRPMLs, CLN7, and CLC-7, has expanded our understanding of the complex regulation of lysosomal ion homeostasis. The regulation of these channels is influenced by various cellular factors, including H+ in the lumen, voltage across the lysosomal membrane, ATP in the cytosol, and growth factors outside the cell. Genetic variations in the channel/transporter genes have been associated with lysosomal storage diseases and neurodegenerative diseases, highlighting the importance of these channels in maintaining cellular homeostasis. Recent studies have suggested that lysosomal channels may be attractive targets for the development of therapeutics for the prevention of and intervention in human diseases. In this review, we will discuss the current state of knowledge on lysosomal ion channels, their functions, and their potential as druggable targets for the treatment of human diseases.
